awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:   Bayesian Methods for the Data-Driven Recovery of Networks: Measuring Impact and Building Resilience in Infrastructures and Communities
awd_abstract_narration:
The US government has increasingly emphasized resilience planning for critical infrastructure, where the combination of withstanding and recovering from disruptions that exacerbate our aging and vulnerable infrastructure systems, constitutes resilience. According to the Department of Homeland Security, the resilient operation of critical infrastructures is "essential to the Nation's security, public health and safety, economic vitality, and way of life." Of particular interest recently is an emphasis on the resilience of communities after a disruptive event, acknowledging that infrastructures do not exist for their own sake but serve society (e.g., citizens, industries), and in some cases, resilient communities assist in protecting the built environment. A resilient community would ideally be able to use the physical infrastructure to effectively communicate risk and coordinate recovery strategies to respond to and recover from disruptions, and ultimately adapt to change and learn from past disruptions. The objective of this work is to develop a new data-driven optimization framework to improve (i) the ability to model the performance of infrastructure networks, and (ii) the ability to plan for the recovery of these networks after a disruption, with an emphasis on community resilience and economic productivity. 

The research approach is composed of three components. The first component develops a new statistical technique, the hierarchical Bayesian kernel method, which integrates the Bayesian property of improving predictive accuracy as data are dynamically obtained, the kernel function that adds specificity to the model and can make nonlinear data more manageable, and the hierarchical property of borrowing information from different sources in sparse and diverse data situations which are common in disruptive events scenarios. The second component develops an infrastructure network recovery optimization formulation that minimizes the larger impact of infrastructure network performance with data-driven (and dynamically updated) hierarchical Bayesian kernel parameters of infrastructure recovery, along with solution techniques that account for the size and dynamic nature of model parameters. The application of the first two integrated components to electric power networks (where impact is measured on the safety and resilience of the community) and inland waterways (where impact is measured on economic productivity across multiple industries), constitutes the third component, offering two application perspectives on the impact of infrastructure network resilience and recovery.

por.por_cntn:
The US government has increasingly emphasized resilience planning for critical infrastructure. Recent planning documents have stated that critical infrastructure "must be secure and able to withstand and rapidly recover from all hazards," where the combination of "withstanding" and "recovering" from disruptions constitutes resilience. The resilient operation of critical infrastructures has been noted as being "essential to the Nation?s security, public health and safety, economic vitality, and way of life." Infrastructure resilience can be thought of as the combination of (i) vulnerability, or the extent to which an infrastructure system's performance is disrupted, and (ii) recoverability, or the trajectory of restoration of the system's performance after its disruption. We the above in mind, this project primarily addressed the recoverability dimension of resilience, focusing on data-driven methods to understand infrastructure performance and the resulting recovery of this performance. We explored several lines of inquiry related to infrastructure performance and recovery, including:

  • New data analysis techniques were developed for understanding infrastructure performance when sparse data are present, namely for disruptions that do not occur frequently but which can have large impacts. These new techniques are based on hierarchical Bayesian methods and were applied to understand water infrastructure component vulnerability, the restoration of electric power networks, and the component importance in an infrastructure network. New hierarchical Bayesian kernel methods resulted from this work and showed tremendous promise in predictive accuracy.
  • Several new advances were made in network resilience optimization. Namely, these optimization models integrate pre- and post-disruption decisions for a defender that is faced with an adversary, and we refer to them as protection-interdiction-restoration models. As these models are quite complex and difficult to solve, we proposed new heuristic techniques to arrive at good approximations using the hybrid integration of exact and metaheuristic approaches.
  • We developed models for describing the socioeconomic impacts on communities of disruptions to underlying infrastructure networks, including optimizing infrastructure restoration from a social vulnerability perspective and understanding the economic value of infrastructure assets. This project also explored important organizational aspects of infrastructure recovery, including integrating policy and technical perspectives and applying machine learning techniques to predict the recovery decisions of other organizational decision-makers in an interdependent infrastructure environment.
  • We explored applications of many of the above techniques to infrastructure investment decision-making for and socioeconomic impacts of inland waterway ports, inland waterway locks and dams, electric power networks, and water infrastructure.

Further, with assistance from the University of Oklahoma and a separate NSF project, we developed a course in Resilience Analytics. Project PI Hiba Baroud gave a guest lecture for the on-campus course, which was recorded and is now available online for a broader audience.
